Dear Maria Madaj:
Attached is the Special Investigation Report for the above referenced facility. Due to the
violations identified in the report, a corrective action plan is required. The corrective action
plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter, must be completed and routed in CWLM,
and must include the following:
• How compliance with each rule will be achieved.
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result
in compliance.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the corrective action for each
violation.
• Specific time frames for each violation as to when the action steps will be
completed or implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is
achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you desire technical assistance in addressing these issues, please feel free to contact
me. In any event, the corrective action plan is due within 15 days. Failure to submit an
acceptable corrective action plan will result in disciplinary action.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager at (517) 899-6024.
P.O. BOX 30650 • LANSING, MICHIGAN 48909
www.michigan.gov • (517) 335-1980

Sincerely,
Lonia Perry Calloway, Licensing Consultant

III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12326 Borrowed home.
Section (1) Before placing a child in a foster home certified by another
Description agency the borrowing agency shall have a record containing all
the following:
1

(a) Approval from the certifying agency authorizing the placement
of a child in the home.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation.
Type
Allegation The agency placed a child in the licensed home of another agency
without that other agency's prior knowledge or consent.
Investigation Interviews:
Complainant
On 2/3/2025 I interviewed Complainant by telephone.
Complainant confirmed the information in the complaint.
Complainant reported their agency, Agency N, who Foster Parent
1 is licensed through, learned of Youth A’s placement in Foster
Parent 1’s foster home inadvertently on 1/29/2025, when looking
into another matter. Complainant saw that Youth A appeared to
have been placed in Foster Parent 1’s home on 1/2/2025.
Complainant attempted to verify the placement via Holy Cross’s
licensing department, who was unaware of the placement being
made prior. Complainant reported after emails to Holy Cross; and
contacts with Youth A’s prior foster parent, Foster Parent 2, and
Foster Care Supervisor the circumstances as to how Youth A’s
placement with Foster Parent 1 came to be was revealed.
Complainant reported Foster Parent 2 was closing out her license
on 1/3/2025 and Holy Cross was scrambling to replace Youth A.
Since Youth A’s sister was already placed with Foster Parent 1,
and Youth A had been having visitations with her sister, Holy
Cross placed Youth A into Foster Parent 1’s home. As to why
Holy Cross failed to inform Agency N, Complainant reported
Foster Care Supervisor was apologetic in his explanation,
reported it was an oversight, that he forgot.
Complainant reported Holy Cross’s actions of placing Youth A into
Foster Parent 1’s foster home caused Foster Parent 1 to be out of
her placement capacity which is for two children as Youth A is the
third child in the home. Complainant reported Agency N had to
search this matter out as opposed to Holy Cross contacting
Agency N to explain their situation and pursue a borrowed bed
agreement. Complainant reported Agency N is still open to
completing a borrowed bed agreement with Holy Cross. Foster
Parent 1 does have the space and capability to accommodate
another child, so Agency N can change Foster Parent 1’s
licensing terms, but Holy Cross should have asked Agency N first
before it acted with Youth A’s placement.
Chief Administrator (CA)
2

I had email contact with CA on 2/3/2025. CA reported being
aware of the circumstances surrounding the complaint.
Foster Care Worker (FCW)
On 2/7/2025 I interviewed FCW by telephone. FCW reported she
was Youth A’s Gaylord Worker prior to Youth A’s case transferring
to Holy Cross’s Muskegon Office just recently. She reported
being on vacation when Youth A’s placement occurred. She
reported prior to her going on vacation at the end of December
2024 Foster Parent 2 was indicating since her license was
expiring soon, that if Youth A did not want to be placed with them
anymore there was no sense for them to renew their license.
FCW said when she returned from vacation on 1/3/2025, Youth A
was already placed with Foster Parent 1. Foster Care Supervisor
(FCS) facilitated the placement; and FCS told her about the
situation. FCW reported Foster Parent 1 and Foster Parent 2 sort
of maneuvered the placement. The two foster homes decided they
were comfortable with Youth A staying with Foster Parent 1
because Youth A was already visiting with her sibling, who is
placed in Foster Parent 1’s home.
FCW reported after her return she did not contact Foster Parent
1’s licensing agency about Youth A’s placement change because
she did not know who was Foster Parent 1’s licensing agency.
She did not contact Holy Cross’s licensing department because
FCS was the person who had worked on Youth A’s placement.
FCW reported she was involved in the TDM/FTM/ (Team Decision
Meeting/Family team meeting) related to Youth A’s placement
change which occurred on 1/17/2025.
Foster Care Supervisor (FCS)
On 2/7/2025, I interviewed FCS by telephone. FCS confirmed the
allegation and information as reported by Complainant and FCW.
FCS said Foster Parent 1 called him over the holiday and he
spoke with her on 1/2/2025. Foster Parent 1 told him that Foster
Parent 2’s license was getting ready to expire, Foster Parent 2 did
not wish to renew their license, and Youth A was visiting with her.
He reported he had not heard about Foster Parent 2 not wanting
to renew. He confirmed with Foster Parent 2 on 1/2/2025 and
Foster Parent 2 reported, “ you know you all need to find a new
placement for her”. FCS reported at that point the agency needed
to replace Youth A and since Youth A was already at Foster
Parent 1’s home, and Foster Parent 1 was open to caring for
Youth A he pursued the placement. He said he was concerned
with where Youth A was going and was trying to get Youth A
placed. He said, “I just forgot to send a notification to a couple of
3

people; my licensing team” and Agency N. He reported the matter
had been rectified and there is now a borrowed bed agreement in
place for Youth A with Agency N.
Reviewed
Youth A’s MISACWIS record which showed:
• A Holy Cross letter of placement showing Youth A (age 14)
was placed with Foster Parent 1 on 1/2/2025.
• Youth A was previously placed in Foster Parent 2’s home
from 1/19/2024-1/2/2025.
Foster Parent 1’s CWLM record which showed:
• Foster Parent 1 was licensed by Agency N in February
2024.
• Foster Parent 1’s licensing terms with respect to capacity
was changed from 2 to 3 on 2/5/2025 so that she could
accommodate placement of a sibling.
• Youth A’s placement with Foster Parent 1 was listed as
2/5/2025.
• The file did not contain a borrowed bed agreement
pertaining to Youth A’s 1/2/2025 placement with Foster
Parent 1 prior to 1/2/2025.
Analysis Based on interviews and documents reviewed the evidence
showed the agency placed Youth A in Agency N’s licensed foster
home of Foster Parent 1 without Agency N’s knowledge or an
approved borrowed bed agreement with Agency N.
Conclusion Violation Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is not in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan,
it is recommended that the current license status be continued.
